bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, November 18, 1936

div1.p: Kean describes the centennial celebration of the Army Medical Library and his award of the Order of Finlay from the Cuban Government.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, November 18, 1936
div1.opener:
Answered
Nov 25-
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Nov. 18, 1936
My dear Truby:
div1.p:
Your recent letter gave me great
pleasure, as it always does to hear
from you.

We have had great doings here in
the past week. In the first place there
was a great and degrified celebration
of the 100th year of the Army Medical
Library - dating it from Lovell's
time. There were a number of dis-
tinguished representatives from
Governments and Medical Institutions
AC
T
at home and abroad. The formal oration by
Sir Humphry Davy Rolleston, Bart.
A fine old Chap who said many fine
things about the Library in a rather in-
distinct tone. The audience of about
600 were distributed upstairs and down
and most of them heard it through loud
speakers much better than we who were
addressed in person by Sir Humphry.
There were very nice refreshments and
many gallons of punch.

There were the usual dinners, etc.
to which we were fortunate enough to
be invited.

The other was my Decoration with
the Grand Cruz de la Ordence Nacional de Mexico
Carlos Finlay. This was presented at a
ceremony yesterday afternoon at the Cuban
Embassy by the Secretary of Sanidad y
Beneficenia a Cabinet Officer and likewise
Grand Chancellor of the Order. It was a very
pretty little ceremony and a number of our
friends were present. The reason for my
being so honored was that I re-organized
the health service of Cuba in 19087
and later was able to get it consolidated
with Beneficencia and given a place in the
Cabinet The citation also mentioned by my
friendship for Dr. Finlay and the fact
that I was one of the early ones to
recognize the value of his work.

I am very much gratified at this recognition
AC
T
by the Cuban Government and in my opinion
the fact that the services were rendered
so long ago increases instead of dimin-
ishing the value of a recognition.
I think that my correspondence with
Dr Ramos Director de Sanidad last
spring and our correspondence about
it may have stirred up old memories
in Cuba. When I got the notice of
the Decoration Cornelia said at once
“I'll bet that General Truby's beauti
ful letter filed which as you know
was filed in the Surgeons General's
office had something to do with this.”
I have recently heard that they are
going to put up a monument
5
at Camp Lazear.

I haven't seen those fine girls of
yours for a long time It would
be a great pleasure to us if
they would drop in on us some
day.

We are happy to know that you are so
happily and beautifully located. Our
only regret is that you are not
nearer us.

Affectionate regards from both
of us to Mrs. Truby
div1.closer:
Always your friend Kean Dictated by me
written by Cornelia
